The highest good and practical postulates
6. The highest good and practical postulates

Kant holds that reason unavoidably produces not only consciousness of
the moral law but also the idea of a world in which there is both
complete virtue and complete happiness, which he calls the highest
good. Our duty to promote the highest good, on Kant’s view, is
the sum of all moral duties, and we can fulfill this duty only if we
believe that the highest good is a possible state of affairs.
Furthermore, we can believe that the highest good is possible only if
we also believe in the immortality of the soul and the existence of
God, according to Kant. On this basis, he claims that it is morally
necessary to believe in the immortality of the soul and the existence
of God, which he calls postulates of pure practical reason. This
section briefly outlines Kant’s view of the highest good and his
argument for these practical postulates in the Critique of
Practical Reason and other works.
